Some time ago, a website highlighted the risks of sharing our whereabouts online. The website's point was that by sharing our location, we're also sharing our movements with many people we may not want to meet. This idea fits with the growing awareness that the internet has both positive and negative effects. The internet offers many opportunities to share our lives with a global audience, but it also has its risks.

In the early days of the internet, a group of pioneers explored these risks and learned from their experiences. They shared their thoughts, photos, and stories online, and many of them faced challenges and consequences. These pioneers, who are now known as bloggers, have already navigated the dangers of the internet and can serve as a guide for the rest of us.

One of these pioneers is Justin Hall, who started posting online in 1994. He shared his life, including his personal thoughts and photos, and his website became popular. However, he faced challenges when he started writing about his personal life, including a romantic relationship. His partner asked him to stop blogging or end the relationship, and he chose to stop blogging.

Another blogger, Heather Armstrong, had a similar experience. She wrote about her job and her colleagues, but an anonymous colleague shared her blog with her bosses, and she lost her job. This experience is an example of the "online distribution effect," where people feel they can say things online that they wouldn't say in person. However, the internet is not a separate reality where we can say anything without consequences. Our online lives are connected to our real lives, and we must be careful about what we share.

Heather Armstrong eventually restarted her blog and focused on her family. She learned that while the internet allows us to share our thoughts and experiences, we should be mindful of the consequences of our actions. We should remember that the internet is a powerful tool that can have a significant impact on our lives.<|eot_id|>

A few years ago, some scientists started warning people about a low-budget film called What the Bleep Do We Know? The film uses a mix of documentary and drama to show that there's a lot we don't understand about the universe. This is not a new idea, as scientists can't claim to know everything. However, some scientists felt strongly enough to issue public warnings, describing the film as "atrocious" or "dangerous". This sparked my curiosity, and I decided to watch the film.

At first, I didn't see what all the fuss was about. Scientists were simply saying that new discoveries were showing that the universe is stranger than we thought. But when the film discussed some of these discoveries, I began to understand the excitement. For example, it talked about how water molecules can be affected by thought. I had heard of a Japanese researcher who found that the shape of a water molecule can change just by the thoughts of people around it. The film showed pictures of ice crystals that looked nice when someone happy was talking to them and nasty when someone in a bad mood was talking to them. Many people find this idea fascinating and compelling, but scientists are more skeptical.

The film's claims are indeed amazing, but they need more evidence to be convincing. The problem is that the film's evidence was not strong enough. The film's claims about water molecules are impressive, but we need more proof that the effect is real. The real issue is that the film's claims are not extreme enough. In reality, scientists have found that the universe is even stranger than the film claims. For example, they have discovered that the universe is made up of an unknown form of matter and is being propelled by a mysterious force called "dark energy". On a smaller scale, neuroscientists have found that our perception of events is delayed by half a second, which is edited out by our brains. Anthropologists have also found the birthplace of modern humans and how they left it to populate the world. Some scientists even think they have found links between the existence of life on Earth and the design of the universe.

Despite what some people might think, science is not complete. In fact, we are further away from knowing everything than ever. The concepts of chaos and quantum uncertainty have shown that we can never know everything. This has led some of the world's leading physicists to try to create a single equation that sums up all the forces and particles of the universe. Many of us believe that the universe is best summed up in one word: incredible.<|eot_id|>

Writing novels is a challenging task, but writing short stories is a joy. It's like comparing planting a forest to planting a garden. Both processes are important, and they complement each other. When I finish a novel, I often want to write some short stories. After completing a group of short stories, I feel like focusing on a novel. I never write short stories while working on a novel, and I never write a novel while working on short stories. This is because writing novels and short stories engage different parts of my brain, and it takes time to switch between them.

I started writing short stories in 1984, and it was a new experience for me. I felt that my writing possibilities expanded, and readers appreciated this new side of me as a writer. One of my early short stories, 'Breaking Waves', was included in my first collection of short stories, Tales from Abroad.

Writing short stories is appealing because they don't take as long to finish as novels. It usually takes me about a week to get a short story into shape, although revisions can be endless. With short stories, I can create a story from a small idea, a word, or an image. It's like jazz improvisation, and the story takes me where it wants to go. Another advantage is that I don't have to worry about failing. Even experienced writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver didn't always write masterpieces. I find this comforting, as I can learn from my mistakes and use them in my next story.

For me, short stories are like an experimental laboratory for my novels. They allow me to try out new ideas and techniques without the pressure of writing a novel. Without short stories, I would find writing novels even more difficult and demanding. My short stories are like footprints I've left behind, and I remember exactly where I wrote each one and how I felt. They are like guideposts to my heart, and it makes me happy to share these intimate feelings with my readers.<|eot_id|>

Science is a complex and multifaceted field that has both fascinated and puzzled humans for centuries. It has the power to cure diseases, improve our daily lives, and even threaten our very existence. Scientists have made incredible discoveries, from understanding the tiny atoms to the vastness of the universe. However, this progress has not been without its challenges and controversies. Established theories have been repeatedly challenged and replaced, and scientists have often clashed over their interpretations.

Science is a constantly evolving field, and its beauty is not always immediately apparent. It requires a deep understanding of complex concepts and a willingness to question and doubt. Despite its limitations, science has the power to change the world, and its impact on society is undeniable.

In the past, science has been characterized by conflict and competition. Scientists have often disagreed on the best approach, and their discoveries have sometimes been met with skepticism or even ridicule. However, these challenges have ultimately led to breakthroughs and a deeper understanding of the world.

Today, science is not just about discovering new facts; it is also about shaping the future. Scientists are working to develop new technologies and solve some of the world's most pressing problems. As a result, it is essential for non-scientists to stay informed about the latest developments and their potential impact on our lives.

In conclusion, science is a dynamic and complex field that has the power to transform our understanding of the world and our place in it. It is a journey that requires patience, persistence, and a willingness to adapt and learn. As we move forward, it is crucial that we recognize the importance of science and its role in shaping our future.<|eot_id|>

For several years, ebook sales grew rapidly. However, from around 2015, major publishers reported a decline in ebook sales or even a complete stop in some cases. This led to doubts about the long-term potential of ebooks in the publishing industry. Some publishing executives admitted that the hype surrounding ebooks might have led to unwise investments, causing them to lose faith in the power of printed books. Despite the fact that digital and print books can coexist, the question of whether ebooks will 'kill' print books still sparks debate.

The idea of a medium replacing another is not new. In the past, critics predicted the demise of radio with the advent of television, and of books with the introduction of audiobooks. But in each case, the old medium found new uses and survived. The same is true for print books, which have adapted to new technologies and continue to thrive.

The idea of the death of the book is not just about ebooks; it's also about our emotional attachment to media. We form strong bonds with objects like books, TVs, and computers, and when a new technology emerges, it disrupts our relationship with the old one. As a result, we often romanticize the past and seek out retro products or older technologies.

The spread of the printing press, the shift from silent to sound movies, and the transition from analog to digital photography are all examples of this phenomenon. The emergence of e-readers has sparked a new appreciation for the tactile qualities of printed books, including their smell.

While the idea of the disappearing book might be alarming, it's also a reflection of our fascination with technology and our fear of change. We use familiar narratives, such as stories of tragedy and loss, to make sense of these changes and to express our emotions. The story of the death of the book is a way to explore our hopes and fears about innovation and transformation.<|eot_id|>

Here is a simplified version of the text, suitable for a C1 learner:

For 18 months, I started my day at 5:30 am, brushed my teeth, made some coffee, and sat down to write about how famous people throughout history managed their daily routines. I wanted to explore how they found time to do their best work, how they organized their days to be creative and productive. By looking at the everyday habits of these people, I hoped to gain a new perspective on their personalities and careers. As the French gastronome Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin once said, "Tell me what you eat, and I'll tell you what you are." I say, "Tell me what time you eat and whether you take a nap, and I'll tell you how creative you are."

My book is about the habits and routines of creative people, not just their work. It's about how they make time for their art and how they prioritize their daily tasks. It's also personal, as I struggle with the same issues in my own life. For example, how do you balance creative work with earning a living? Is it better to focus on one project or work on multiple things at once? When you have too much to do, do you have to sacrifice something, or can you find ways to work more efficiently?

I don't claim to have all the answers, but I've tried to provide examples of how successful and talented people have handled these challenges. I wanted to show how their daily routines influenced their work and vice versa. The title of my book is "Daily Rituals," but I focused on people's routines and habits. A routine can be ordinary, but it can also be a powerful tool for achieving your goals. The psychologist William James believed that having a routine can free up your mind to focus on more important things.

I actually got the idea for this book because I was procrastinating on a writing task one Sunday afternoon. Instead of working, I was tidying my office and making coffee. As a morning person, I'm more focused in the mornings, but I'm not very productive in the afternoons. I started searching the internet for information on other writers' schedules and found it fascinating. I decided to create a blog to collect these stories and eventually turned it into this book. The book is based on my blog, but it's more extensive and better researched. I've tried to let my subjects speak for themselves, using quotes from their letters, diaries, and interviews. I've also included summaries of their routines from secondary sources. I want to thank the many researchers and scholars whose work I drew upon to make this book possible. You can find a list of my sources in the Notes section, which I hope will also serve as a guide for further reading.<|eot_id|>

Howard became interested in paleontology when he was six years old. His family couldn't afford a trip to Spain, so they went to the English coast instead. On the beach, Howard found an ammonite, a type of fossil. He decided he wanted to become a paleontologist and focus on the earliest fossils. After finishing his university studies, Howard knew he wanted to work on delicate creatures found on grey rocks. He completed his PhD thesis and was unsure if he would get a job. He applied for an assistant lecturer position at Tavistock College in London, but wasn't hopeful.

On the day of the interview, the professor who was supposed to chair the panel had a disagreement with his wife and ended up in the hospital. A different professor, who didn't like Howard's mentor, was appointed to the panel and helped Howard get the job. Howard was surprised but grateful.

Months later, a colleague explained the situation to him, and Howard realized that he had gotten the job due to a personal connection rather than his qualifications. He was slightly disappointed but happy to have the job and be able to do the work he loved.

Howard often contrasted his professional life, where he could plan and control his work, with the unpredictability of his personal life. His professional life was affected when his briefcase containing his lecture notes was stolen at an Underground station. He reported the theft and postponed his lecture. Later, he met a colleague who was hosting a curator from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. The curator mentioned a new collection of fossils that Howard was eager to study. Without the theft, Howard might not have learned about the collection and might not have had the opportunity to secure his professional future.

Within an hour, Howard adjusted his plans and decided to visit the museum in Nairobi instead of attending a conference in Stockholm or taking a field trip to Scotland.<|eot_id|>

Charles Spence, a professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University, is fascinated by the way our senses interact to shape our perception of food and drink. He and his team are exploring how to make unusual foods more appealing, like ice cream made from bee larvae. Spence's research has a significant impact on the food industry, from giant food companies to high-end restaurants. He has discovered that various factors, such as who we eat with, how food is presented, and the background noise, can affect our taste.

Spence's book, "The Perfect Meal", is filled with fascinating insights. For example, did you know that the person who orders first in a restaurant tends to enjoy their food more? And that we eat more when eating with others? His laboratory at Oxford is surprisingly low-tech, with soundproof booths and old audio-visual equipment. This allows him to work with chefs who can't fund academic research themselves.

Spence's work is often funded by major food companies. Historically, this type of research was seen as less prestigious, but since the government has emphasized the importance of making research relevant and impactful, this type of collaboration has become more popular. Spence is currently helping famous brands reduce salt and sugar in their products. He points out that it's in their interest to do so, as it helps loyal customers stay healthy.

Spence has also worked with famous chefs, like Heston Blumenthal, to create unique dishes. For example, the "Sound of the Sea" dish, which uses sound to enhance the flavor. His research has also shown that certain types of music can affect our perception of sweetness and bitterness. An airline is planning to use his research to match music with food, and a well-known brand has released a smartphone app that plays music while your ice cream softens.

At home, Spence and his family enjoy experimenting with food and sound. They have had dinner parties with unusual themes, such as eating rabbit with fur-wrapped cutlery or playing with light bulbs. For Spence, the line between his laboratory and his home is blurred, as he sees his work as an extension of his daily life.<|eot_id|>

Our brains are constantly bombarded with information, including facts, rumors, and opinions. We need to filter out what's important and ignore the rest. At the same time, we're doing more tasks than ever before. We're responsible for making our own travel arrangements, finding what we need in shops, and managing our daily lives. Our smartphones help us stay connected, but they also contribute to the pressure to cram as much as possible into our busy lives.

However, our brains are not designed to multitask effectively. We may think we're doing several things at once, but in reality, we're rapidly switching between tasks, which can be stressful and inefficient. Multitasking can lead to mental fatigue, stress, and decreased productivity. It can also make us more prone to making mistakes and poor decisions.

Research has shown that multitasking can reduce our cognitive abilities, making it harder to focus and make good decisions. Even simple tasks like checking email can be distracting and take up a significant amount of mental energy. In fact, the constant stream of emails can be overwhelming, making it difficult to get anything else done.

The constant pressure to multitask and respond to emails can be exhausting. It's no wonder that our brains are overwhelmed and our productivity suffers as a result.<|eot_id|>

In a Swedish zoo, a chimpanzee named Santino broke up concrete at night and threw the pieces at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In the US, female bats help other female bats who are having trouble giving birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, people thought animals just behaved in certain ways and that was it. They didn't think animals had feelings or moral values. However, recent research on animals like bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens has changed this perspective. Scientists are now exploring the emotions of animals, and this has led to a debate about whether animals are conscious and have moral values.

This debate has also raised questions about animal welfare and our treatment of them. For example, a study showed that cows that figured out how to open a gate to get food were happier than those that didn't. If cows enjoy problem-solving, what does this mean for the way we raise and eat them? Some experts believe that this research means we should stop eating meat, while others think we should just be more considerate of animal welfare.

There are different opinions on this issue, and some scientists think that we should stop attributing human-like qualities to animals. Others believe that animals have a simpler way of thinking, but still have feelings and values. The debate is not just about science, but also about philosophy and our relationship with animals. It's a complex issue that may not have a clear answer.

Note: I made the following changes:

* Simplified sentence structures and vocabulary
* Removed complex scientific jargon and technical terms
* Added transitional phrases to connect ideas and make the text flow better
* Reduced the number of abstract concepts and philosophical ideas
* Emphasized the main points and ideas, and rephrased some sentences to make them clearer and more concise.<|eot_id|>

Critical thinking is a way to understand and analyze what we read or hear. Adrian West, a researcher at the Edward de Bono Foundation, believes that argument is a way to find the truth. However, he also thinks that technology is changing the way we approach complex problems and making it harder to think critically. We are exposed to more information, but this can be overwhelming and make it difficult to make good decisions.

In fact, the amount of data and information available does not necessarily mean we have more knowledge or make better decisions. According to West, the quality of our thinking has not improved despite the abundance of information. The National Endowment for the Arts reports that reading has declined by 10 percentage points, and this trend is accelerating.

Many experts, including Patricia Greenfield, a psychology professor, think that the focus on visual media is a problem. She believes that a decline in reading has contributed to a decline in critical thinking. People are now more focused on instant media and multi-tasking, rather than focusing on one thing.

It's difficult to say exactly how technology affects critical thinking. However, it's clear that technology can be both positive and negative. For example, a computer game can promote critical thinking or hinder it. Reading on the internet can improve our ability to analyze, but following links can make it harder to think deeply.

According to Greenfield, exposure to technology changes the way people think. She has analyzed over 50 studies on learning and technology and found that reading enhances thinking and imagination, while visual media can improve some types of information processing. However, most visual media do not allow time for reflection, analysis, or imagination.

The outcome is that many people, especially younger ones, are not reaching their full potential. The way society views technology affects how we perceive critical thinking. The relationship between video games and cognition is a good example of this. James Paul Gee, a professor of educational psychology, argues that video games are not only a form of entertainment but also a tool for learning. In fact, an increasing amount of evidence suggests that video games can help build smarter children with better reasoning skills.

Games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and analytical skills in virtual environments that resemble the real world. They also give players the freedom to explore ideas and concepts that might be inaccessible otherwise. In the digital age, it's clear that we need to understand the subtleties of how technology affects thinking and analysis.<|eot_id|>

Matthew Crawford is a philosopher who has written several books about how we should live our lives. When he's not writing, he works as a motorcycle mechanic, a job he chose after becoming disillusioned with office work. His latest book is about how to cope with the demands of modern life.

Crawford noticed that advertisements are now everywhere, even when we're just trying to do simple tasks like paying with our credit cards. He thinks that these constant demands on our attention are making it harder for us to focus on what's important to us. We're also losing the ability to have conversations with strangers and enjoy simple activities like chatting with friends.

Crawford believes that technology, such as video games and social media, is partly to blame. These things reflect our desires and can take over our lives. He's not the only one who thinks this; many people feel overwhelmed by the constant stream of information and notifications.

It's not just technology that's the problem, though. Crawford thinks that the way we live our lives is also to blame. We're so used to having constant choices and options that we're losing the ability to control ourselves. This is affecting our relationships and our ability to connect with others.

Crawford suggests that we need to find ways to engage with the world in a more meaningful way. He thinks that activities like cooking, playing sports, or riding a motorcycle can help us do this. These activities require us to focus on the present moment and to interact with others in a more authentic way.

He also believes that we need to find ways to regulate noise and distractions in public spaces. This could help us to focus and be more present in our daily lives. By doing so, we can regain control over our attention and build stronger relationships with others.

Note: I've kept the original text's tone and style, but simplified the vocabulary and sentence structure to make it more accessible to a C1 learner. I've also condensed some of the ideas and examples to make the text more concise.<|eot_id|>

Here is a simplified version of the text, suitable for a C1 learner:

"What do you do for a living?" This is a common question, and people usually answer it quickly. But when you're a philosopher, it's harder. Saying you're a philosopher can sound pretentious, like you're claiming to be special. In reality, philosophers are just like everyone else, but the idea that they're somehow superior has stuck around.

One reason for this is that philosophers have a reputation for judging others and celebrating intellectual pursuits. Aristotle, a famous philosopher, believed that a life of contemplation was the most virtuous. Many modern philosophers disagree, but the idea persists. Another philosopher, Socrates, said that an unexamined life is not worth living. This means that a life that just follows the crowd without thinking about it is unsatisfying. 

Philosophy is often associated with deep thinking and reflection. But it doesn't have to be that way. It's about looking closely at the everyday things that make up our lives and making sure they're worth doing. It's not about being a sage or a genius; it's about being practical and sharing knowledge with others.

Another reason philosophers are misunderstood is that academic philosophy has become isolated from everyday life. Philosophers often write for other experts, using specialized language that's hard to understand. This makes it seem like philosophy is only for academics, not for ordinary people. But philosophy should be for everyone, and it can help us make sense of our lives.

I often describe myself as an ethicist, because I work in the area of ethics, which is about evaluating human behavior. But I'm starting to realize that this label doesn't capture the full range of my work. Ethics is often associated with rules and laws, but it's also about exploring how we think about responsibility, art, and consumerism. Philosophy can help us examine our daily habits and behaviors, and this can be beneficial for everyone.

Note: I've kept the main ideas and arguments of the original text, but simplified the language and sentence structure to make it more accessible to a C1 learner. I've also removed some of the more technical terms and jargon to make the text more readable.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text for a C1 learner:

Foodies and those who love food often think that thinking deeply about what and how we eat can make our culinary experiences even more enjoyable. However, philosophers have traditionally focused on other topics rather than food itself. When philosophers have talked about eating, it was usually just a metaphor for something else, like gaining knowledge. Some philosophical discussions about food seem to be about food at first, but upon closer examination, they are actually discussing something else. 

The ancient Greek philosopher Epicurus believed in pursuing pleasure and avoiding pain, but he didn't just mean eating and drinking. Despite this, his name is often associated with a love of food and drink. Restaurants, food shops, and online recipe sites use his name to suggest that their products are approved by a famous philosopher. 

Food is a social and cultural aspect of our lives. The food we eat comes from our communities and is shared with others. These communities provide us with friends and family, as well as the infrastructure to grow and distribute food. Food is unique because we interact with it more frequently and in a more fundamental way than with any other commodity. This makes it an important topic for philosophical discussion. 

When we eat, critics will write and talk about it. But why do they get to decide what's good or bad? One philosopher suggests that tasting food is not a special skill, but rather that influential food critics are just better at describing what they taste. 

Another aspect of food is aesthetics. We talk about beautiful paintings or music, but not the taste of food. Some philosophers argue that, with the rise of modern gastronomy, food should be considered an aesthetic experience like sculpture or poetry. However, food is destroyed when we eat it, unlike other aesthetic objects that can be appreciated over time. 

There are also ethical issues surrounding food. We can ask questions like "What should we eat?" and "How should we produce food?" The answers will often reveal our values and beliefs. Philosophers will examine these questions and engage in debates about them. 

Cooking at home is different from cooking in a restaurant. Home cooks have a special responsibility to their guests, which is based on the relationships of love and friendship. In contrast, restaurant chefs have obligations to their employers and the food itself, which means their kitchens are not open to everyone and their relationships are with colleagues, not friends. 

A recent essay explored how food and dining can bring people together across cultures. This can happen in two ways: by learning to appreciate other cultures' foods and by sharing meals with people from other cultures. This practice has a long history in international diplomacy. The essay is full of interesting examples and anecdotes that make this aspect of food philosophy come alive for the general reader.<|eot_id|>

Rob Daviau, an American game designer, created 'legacy' board games. He wanted to make games more exciting and challenging than the ones he played as a child. He thought, "Why not add a storyline? Why not make decisions permanent?" He took an old game called Risk and turned it into Risk Legacy. Players could tear up cards, damage the board, or open new rules. The game lasted for a set number of sessions, and players' actions had lasting effects.

Daviau worked on a legacy version of Pandemic, a popular cooperative game where players work together to save the world from diseases. His next project was SeaFall, a game set in the age of sail. Players became sailors, exploring the world and conquering new lands. To make sure the story didn't fall apart, designers had to consider all possible player choices. They tested the game with players to see how it would unfold.

Daviau thought legacy games would be a niche idea, but they became very popular. Many players loved the concept, saying it was a new level of excitement and commitment. They enjoyed the feeling of being part of an unfolding adventure, like a TV series. Game designers like Matt Leacock compared the process to writing a novel. They needed to have an idea of how the story would end and begin, but also leave room for surprises.

Colby Dauch, a game publisher, thinks the legacy format changed the way people think about board games. He believes it's a game-changer. Daviau, however, thinks that soon gamers will want something new and different.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>
Here is the simplified text for a C1 learner:

In 2016, an octopus named Inky escaped from a tank at the National Aquarium in New Zealand. He climbed out of the tank, crossed the floor, and squeezed into a narrow drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was widely shared online and was like something from a children's movie. One of the reasons people enjoyed the story was because it's fun to imagine animals as being like us. Octopuses, in particular, are fascinating because they are very intelligent, but their bodies are very different from ours. They can open jars, recognize faces, and even play games. Some people think it's unscientific to attribute human-like qualities to animals, but Dr. Frans de Waal, a scientist who studies primates, argues that it's actually the opposite. He says that many people have a tendency to underestimate the intelligence of animals, which he calls "anthropodenial". De Waal has spent decades studying animal cognition and has found that many animals exhibit behaviors that were once thought to be unique to humans, such as the ability to think about the past and future, show empathy, and understand the intentions of others. In fact, animals are much smarter than we often give them credit for.

In the past, people believed that animals were capable of complex thought and even put them on trial for crimes. However, with the rise of behaviorism in the 20th century, the focus shifted to conditioning animals through rewards and punishments, and many people began to view animals as stimulus-response machines or robots. This change in perspective coincided with the destruction of animal habitats, pollution, and the development of methods for raising livestock that ignored animal welfare. Fortunately, de Waal believes that we are now moving away from this dark period and recognizing that animal cognition is on the same spectrum as human intelligence, even if it's not at the same level. To test animal intelligence, de Waal suggests designing tests that take into account the specific abilities and traits of each species. For example, squirrels are great at remembering where they hide nuts, while humans need apps to find their phones.

In her book, naturalist Sy Montgomery notes that if an octopus were to test human intelligence, it might test us on our ability to change the color of our skin, and we would likely fail. De Waal is skeptical of Inky's escape story, but he recognizes the power of viral stories to raise awareness about animal intelligence. He once conducted an experiment to see if capuchin monkeys can experience envy, and the results were surprising. The study was published in a scientific journal, but it was a short video clip of the experiment that really convinced people of the findings.<|eot_id|>

Here is a simplified version of the passage for a C1 learner:

The field of robotics is expected to bring about a significant technological shift, comparable to the Industrial Revolution. While robots have been used in the automotive and manufacturing sectors for a long time, experts predict that their use will soon expand to many other industries. However, many people are not prepared for this change. Some people think that robots will replace most human jobs, but they also believe that their own jobs will remain unchanged. This is an example of an optimistic bias.

Robots are already being used in various sectors, such as construction and retail. For example, a robot developed by an Australian company can lay 1,000 bricks in an hour, which would take two human bricklayers a day to do. Another robot, called Tally, can help keep supermarket shelves stocked and priced.

Advocates of robotics argue that new, high-skilled jobs will be created for technicians and programmers. Critics, on the other hand, warn that we should not underestimate the importance of human skills in the workplace.

Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, a leading expert on robotics, has researched how this technology is shaping the future of work. He predicts that within two years, one-third of robots will be able to work with other robots and humans safely.
